awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Real-time Investigations of Anisotropic Nanoparticle Aggregation and Consequences for Deposition in Porous Media
awd_abstract_narration:
Nanoparticles are prevalent in nature and widely produced in a variety of shapes and sizes in ever-increasing quantities. These nanoparticles often aggregate in water, and thus they typically transport and deposit in environmental media in the form of aggregates instead of individual nanoparticles. However, how the structure of nanoparticle aggregates influence nanoparticles' movement in the environment is not well understood. The overall objective of this project is to better understand the interactions of nanoparticulate aggregates with environmental media and how these interactions can be governed by the shape and size of the individual nanoparticles. Findings from this work can benefit the design and optimization of a broad range of engineered processes, such as filter-based water treatment, groundwater remediation, and drug delivery. This project will also benefit K-12 education through outreach activities involving videos and pictures of nanomaterials. Additional outreach programs include 1) the Summer Coding Camp, at Ohio University to introduce middle school girls to the STEM fields, and 2) various science activities offered by Nebraska Center for Materials and Nanosciences at the University of Nebraska-Lincoln to broaden the exposure of K-12 students to materials science and engineering, nanoscience, and nanotechnology. In addition, the PIs will leverage the existing REU programs at the University of Nebraska-Lincoln to train Ohio university undergraduate students during summers. 

In the past, nanoparticle aggregation and deposition were often studied separately, with limited research linking mobility of nanoparticles in environmental media to the structure of nanoparticle aggregates. However, new evidence suggests that anisotropic nanoparticles, the most common form of nanoparticles in the environment, often form non-compact aggregates. The formation of these non-compact aggregates cannot be explained by classic colloidal aggregation theories. Moreover, non-compact aggregates undergo unusual deposition and modify hydrodynamics in environmental porous media, which is not described by the classical filtration theory. Acquisition and integration of quantitative data from all steps involved in nanoparticle aggregation and deposition is critically needed. The research objectives of this project include: 1) Quantifying the anisotropic diffusion dynamics of nanoparticles with various aspect ratios in water; 2) Elucidating the role of the shape of primary nanoparticles on the formation kinetics and morphological structure of aggregates; and 3) Evaluating the impact of aggregate structure on the transport and deposition of aggregates in environmental porous media. Hematite nanoparticles with different aspect ratios (i.e., nanosphere, nanorod, nanodisk) will be synthesized in the study. Advanced techniques will be employed to visualize and quantify nanoparticle diffusion, aggregation, transport, and deposition in environmental matrices. Furthermore, the experimental data will be used to update classical filtration theory for predicting nanoparticle behaviors in porous media. The expected intellectual outcomes from this work will include development of a series of quantitative metrics from measurements of anisotropic diffusion, aggregate formation, and aggregate deposition and flow dynamics in porous media. These quantitative characterizations will allow us to elucidate the mechanisms which control anisotropic nanoparticle aggregation and deposition in environmental porous media. This will, in turn, improve the utility of colloidal science principles in understanding and predicting nanoparticle behaviors, such as colloid Brownian motion theory, colloid aggregation theory, and the classical filtration theory.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

por.por_cntn:
Nanoparticles tend to cluster together in water, causing them to be transported and deposited in the environment as aggregates instead of individual particles. This collaborative project between Ohio University and the University of Nebraska-Lincoln aims to explore how the anisotropic properties of nanoparticles, such as their size and shape, affect the formation of these aggregates. Additionally, the project seeks to determine how the structure of these aggregates ultimately affects their transport behavior in porous media like groundwater.

The team from Ohio University is focusing on studying the kinetics and structure of aggregate formation, while the researchers from the University of Nebraska-Lincoln are investigating how the structure of these aggregates influences their transport and deposition within porous media.

The intellectual merit of this project includes the following:

1)    we have found that the size distribution of the primary particles does not affect the scaling behavior of aggregate growth but causes a delay in rapid aggregation. The resulting aggregate’s fractal dimension distribution is substantially modified, indicating that the primary particle distribution has a noteworthy effect on the aggregate structure.

2)    we have also found a new mechanism governing nanoparticle aggregation under high ionic strength conditions representing ocean water and wastewater. Our results show that the tendency of nanoplastics to aggregate increases with ionic strength due to the depletion of clusters of ions from their surface, rather than through classic DLVO forces. 

3)    we have developed a Random Forest model that predicts aggregate fractal dimensions with just four parameters. The model accurately predicts fractal dimensions of nano to micro-sized particle aggregates. It works when salt addition/concentration is the dominant aggregation mechanism and can be used in natural or engineering settings.

4)    we have found that the fractal dimension of aggregates formed by anisotropic nanoparticles is independent of their chemical composition but is influenced by their size distribution and shape.

5)    we have also discovered that the effect of aliphatic sulfur on the formation of asphaltene nanoaggregates is non-monotonic and varies depending on molecular structure. Aliphatic sulfur affects the structure of rod-like nanoaggregates, especially when asphaltene molecules have small aromatic cores. Repulsive forces between aliphatic sulfur and neighboring molecules' side chains explain the polydispersity in the nanoaggregates and corresponding colloidal aggregates.

Results from this work were presented at national and international scientific conferences and published in peer-reviewed scientific journals.

The project has also provided several broader impacts including the following:

1)    we have provided research opportunities to undergraduate students, including summer interns, utilizing the OU internal Program to Aid Career Exploration (PACE). Half of these student researchers are first-generation college students who apply for need-based scholarships.

2)    we have participated in several K-12 outreach programs, including the OHIO Summer Coding Camp and the STEM EXPO for Younger Members Central OH ASCE. The OHIO coding camp was a one-week program introducing middle school girls to STEM fields. During these programs, we conducted hands-on microscopy experiments that helped the students understand the different sizes involved when working at various scales. We also taught the students about nanoparticles and how they impact the environment. These experiences allowed the students to better understand nanotechnology, STEM, and their potential environmental impact.

3)    we have incorporated the recent findings from this project into the current graduate-level curriculum called -Chemical Fate and Transport, by creating new modules. These modules concentrate on how the properties of nanoparticles influence their stability and compare them to traditional theoretical frameworks like DLVO theory.

4)    we have broadened results dissemination through class materials, conference presentations, group meetings, and meetings with collaborators.

5)    we have systematically and cross-disciplinarily trained graduate students, including PhD students and postdocs, involved in this project with a broad skill set that includes in-situ microscopy, image analysis, machine learning, and molecular simulation.

This project addresses the lack of knowledge regarding how the properties of anisotropic nanoparticles affect their aggregate formation and their transport and fate in the porous media environment, as per the literature review. The research analyzed nanoparticles’size, size distribution, and shape effects on the aggregate structure. The information obtained can contribute to filling the gaps in understanding nanoparticle interactions with environmental media and hopefully encourage future studies related to nanoparticle stability in the fields of environmental risk, water treatment, and wastewater treatment.

 


Last Modified: 04/26/2024
Modified by: Lei Wu
